title: Japanese family appear in court charged with preventing lawful burial of relative found dead in house in North Yorkshire
text:
The family of a Japanese woman, whose decomposing remains were found in a cottage in a North Yorkshire village, have appeared in court charged with preventing her lawful burial.

Rina Yasutake, 49, a talented artist who studied at Cambridge University, is thought to have been dead for at least six weeks when her body was discovered in bed at the family home in picturesque Helmsley in September last year.

It is understood police discovered her severely decomposing remains after being alerted by local pharmacy staff who had become concerned by the excessive amount of surgical spirit her brother and sister had been purchasing.

The pharmacist is also alleged to have reported to police that Ms Yasutake's siblings, "smelled of dead bodies", when they came into the branch.

Yoshika Yasutake, 52, her brother Takahiro Yasutake, 47, and their elderly mother Michiko Yasutake, 76, all appeared before Scarborough magistrates' court accused of preventing the lawful and decent burial of a dead body without lawful excuse.

They spoke through an interpreter to confirm their names and address, no pleas were entered and the case was sent to York Crown Court, where it will be heard in front of a judge on December 2nd.
